title: UK cars need to display GB stickers when visiting Republic of Ireland after Brexit
text:
The Government has advised all UK motorists planning to drive to the Republic of Ireland after Brexit that they will need to display a GB sticker on their cars.

The recommendation applied to vehicles registered in all parts of the UK, including Northern Ireland.

The requirement for the stickers is currently not strictly enforced, but will be a must following Britain's proposed departure from the EU when the ‘GB’ letters on the blue background of a number plate will no longer suffice.

Sticker stipulation: All UK-registered cars will need to display a GB sticker when driving in any of the 27 EU nations, including the Republic of Ireland, post Brexit, the government says

The sticker, a white oval containing the letters GB, must be displayed at the rear of all UK vehicles when in use in any of the 27 EU nations.

They're generally cheap to buy online, or from retailers such as Halfords.

While rules have always stipulated that UK motors need to display a GB logo, until Brexit a number plate with GB on the blue edge have been deemed fit for purpose in the Republic of Ireland.

Not all cars have these plates, and ones without currently should display one of the removable stickers.

A number plate with 'GB' on the blue edge have been deemed fit for purpose in the Republic of Ireland

However advice issued by the Government says that UK motorists will need to display the sticker as a requirement under the 1949 Geneva Convention on Road Traffic once Britain's divorce from the EU is complete.

RAC spokesman Simon Williams warned the new law could cause problems for those travelling abroad - particular those who regularly cross the Irish border.

The announcement forms part of a raft of new Brexit advice as the government steps up its preparations before the planned October 31st departure date.

'While it might seem ridiculous that this will no longer be enough to let authorities know a vehicle is registered in the UK, the latest advice from the government is clear,' Williams said.

'Anyone travelling to an EU country, including the Republic of Ireland, must display a separate white oval GB sticker on the rear of their vehicle.'

The Association of British Insurers (ABI) said failure to display one of the stickers would not invalidate a motorist's insurance, but still advised for all drivers to follow all relevant requirements.

The RAC warned drivers that more changes to driving overseas could come depending on the conditions attached to the UK’s departure from the European Union and what, if any, deal is reached.

Previous government advice has stated that motorists may require an International Driving Permit (IDP) alongside their UK licence to legally drive abroad.

The stickers are cheap to buy from outlets such as Halfords or online

In anticipation of a no-deal Brexit at the original leave date of 29 March, requests for IDPs shot up by more than a fifth in the preceding months as motorists took all necessary precautions for driving overseas.

If Britain does leave the EU with no deal at the end of October it will be more difficult for drivers to get one of the permits that it previously had been.

Motoring groups like the AA had been allowed to issue them, but as of February drivers can only obtain them from one of 2,500 issuing Post Offices.
